title: Monetize Facebook Marketplace without killing growth
prompt: Facebook Marketplace has 1B monthly users but monetization is near-zero. Leadership wants to introduce seller fees (5% transaction fee) without killing growth. Craigslist died trying this. eBay succeeded. You're the PM. How do you monetize without destroying the free marketplace culture?
problemDefinition: Huge user base with near-zero revenue creates pressure to monetize
Marketplace culture is explicitly free and fee-sensitive
Competitive risk: fees could push sellers to free alternatives

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Interview power sellers and buyers to map price sensitivity and value perception.

options.label: Pick the wedge
options.text: Start with a narrow category where value is highest (e.g., cars).

options.label: Ship fees now
options.text: Introduce a small fee immediately and measure churn in real time.

options.label: Experiment loop
options.text: Run pricing experiments to find elasticity and optimize conversion.

options.label: Power sellers
options.text: Charge high-volume sellers who already monetize through Marketplace.

options.label: Buyers
options.text: Add buyer protection or escrow fees tied to trust value.

options.label: Category-based
options.text: Charge only in high-value categories (cars, electronics).

options.label: Everyone
options.text: Flat fee everywhere and iterate on fallout quickly.

options.label: Value perception
options.text: If users don't see added value, fees will feel like a tax.

options.label: Strategic focus
options.text: If we monetize too broadly, we lose the core marketplace.

options.label: Speed
options.text: If we don't move fast, leadership will force a bad fee rollout.

options.label: Elasticity
options.text: If price elasticity is high, a tiny fee can crash volume.

theSplit.question: Should Facebook Marketplace introduce fees broadly or only in a focused wedge first?

sides.reasoning: Monetize where value is clear before touching the broader marketplace.
Price elasticity needs real data; broad rollout yields signal fast.
Map user value perception before choosing any fee model.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Prove value exchange before charging fees
cagan.spicyQuote: If users feel you're taxing their free marketplace, you've destroyed the trust that made it valuable.
breakdown: Value risk: do users see a clear value exchange for fees?
Viability risk: fees may kill liquidity and ad revenue
Usability risk: fee confusion drives churn
The best companies validate value before monetization
solution: Test fees in a narrow category with clear value
Offer seller tools or protection as the value exchange
Measure impact on liquidity and trust
Scale only if value risk clears
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster will ship fees without proving value and call it learning. Lenny will optimize elasticity, but if users don't trust the value exchange, the loop is broken. Doshi's wedge is right but still needs hard validation. Torres aligns on discovery but must tie it to viability outcomes.

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map value perception and price sensitivity before charging
torres.spicyQuote: Fees are just a tax unless we've proven the opportunity they're solving.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (revenue without liquidity loss)
Map opportunities: trust, protection, seller tools
Weekly interviews with buyers and sellers
Test value exchange before pricing
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Run weekly interviews + prototype tests
Test value propositions before fee rollout
Use evidence to choose the fee model
torres.disagreement: Cagan's risk framing is aligned, but this requires continuous evidence, not a one-off pilot. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship fees without understanding value perception. Doshi's wedge is fine, but the wedge still needs opportunity validation.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.spicyQuote: Broad fees are the peanut-butter strategy of monetization. Choose a wedge or burn the marketplace.
breakdown: This is a strategy decision disguised as a pricing tweak
Opportunity cost: broad fees risk the whole marketplace
Pre-mortem: liquidity collapse, trust loss, seller churn
Wedge monetization is the leverage move
solution: Pick a high-value category wedge
Design value exchange specific to that wedge
Run a pre-mortem and define success criteria
Expand only if the wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Torres and Cagan will spend too long validating while leadership pushes a broad fee. Execution AI Monster will ship fees everywhere and trigger backlash. Lenny will optimize elasticity, but without a strategic wedge it's still a tax.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Run pricing experiments to find elasticity fast
lenny.spicyQuote: You don't guess price sensitivity at 1B users. You experiment and let the data speak.
breakdown: Define activation: successful transaction with fee applied
Map loop: listing -> sale -> buyer trust -> repeat
Benchmark against eBay and OfferUp
Run pricing experiments to find elasticity
solution: Instrument the funnel and run fee experiments
Segment by category and seller type
Scale the highest-revenue / lowest-churn model
Iterate weekly based on data
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants more discovery, but pricing elasticity is a data problem. Cagan's risk framing is right, but experiments are how you answer it. Doshi's wedge is helpful, but you still need the loop and data. Execution AI Monster is fast, but without measurement discipline, speed is noise.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship a small fee now and learn from backlash
exec.spicyQuote: You can debate fees for six months or collect real data in six days. Ship it.
breakdown: Building is discovery   ship to learn
At this scale, you need real data fast
Small fees are reversible if backlash hits
Speed beats perfect pricing models
solution: Introduce a 1-2% fee to 5% of users
Monitor churn and transaction volume daily
Iterate pricing weekly
Scale only if metrics hold
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be researching while leadership forces a broad fee. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but don't wait for perfect experiments   ship and learn.

mvpOptions.name: Category Wedge Monetization
mvpOptions.reason: Charge only in high-value categories to protect core liquidity.

mvpOptions.name: Value Exchange Bundle
mvpOptions.reason: Add seller protection tools before introducing fees.

mvpOptions.name: Pricing Experiment MVP
mvpOptions.reason: Run elasticity tests to find the fee sweet spot.

mvpOptions.name: Rapid Fee Pilot
mvpOptions.reason: Ship small fees quickly and iterate on backlash data.

premortem: Liquidity collapse: sellers leave and buyers can't find inventory
Trust backlash: users see fees as a tax and stop using Marketplace
Revenue mirage: fees rise but total GMV falls
vitalQuestion: What value exchange is strong enough that sellers will tolerate a fee?
